tasks.title: Enhance CSV Parser for Edge Cases
tasks.description: Improve smart CSV parser to handle quoted fields and malformed data more robustly
tasks.details: Add support for CSV files with quoted fields containing commas (e.g. "1 299 000,00 zÅ‚"). Implement better detection of separators (comma vs semicolon). Add validation for malformed rows to provide better error messages to users.
tasks.testStrategy: Test with various CSV formats including quoted fields, different separators, and malformed data. Verify parser correctly handles Polish numerical formats and currency values

subtasks.title: Enhance CSV separator detection and quoted field parsing
subtasks.description: Improve the parseCSVLine method to better handle CSV files with quoted fields containing commas and more robust separator detection
subtasks.details: Modify the parseCSVLine method in smart-csv-parser.ts (lines 714-747) to implement more sophisticated separator detection logic. Currently it uses simple line.includes(';') check. Enhance to analyze the entire file structure, count separators, and detect patterns. Improve quoted field handling to properly parse values like '1 299 000,00 zÅ‚' that contain commas within quotes. Add support for different quote styles and escaped characters.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test with various CSV formats: semicolon vs comma separated, quoted fields with commas, Polish currency formats, and mixed separator files. Verify parser correctly identifies separator and extracts quoted values.

subtasks.title: Implement malformed row detection and validation
subtasks.description: Add comprehensive validation for malformed CSV rows with better error reporting and recovery mechanisms
subtasks.details: Enhance the parseData method (lines 1043-1181) to implement robust row validation. Currently it skips rows with less than 50% of expected columns. Add detailed validation rules: check for rows with wrong column count, detect rows with all empty values, identify rows with invalid data types in critical fields. Implement recovery strategies for partially malformed rows. Add specific error messages for each type of malformation to help users understand and fix their data.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test with intentionally malformed CSV files: rows with missing columns, extra columns, completely empty rows, and rows with invalid data types. Verify appropriate error messages and recovery behavior.

subtasks.title: Add intelligent encoding detection for Polish characters
subtasks.description: Implement automatic encoding detection to handle CSV files with Polish characters in various encodings
subtasks.details: Create encoding detection logic in the upload API route (around line 125 where detectEncodingAndDecode is called). The function exists but needs enhancement. Implement detection for common encodings: UTF-8, UTF-8 BOM, Windows-1250 (CP1250), ISO-8859-2. Use byte order marks and character frequency analysis to detect encoding. Handle conversion errors gracefully and provide fallback mechanisms. Add logging to help debug encoding issues.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test with CSV files saved in different encodings containing Polish characters (Ä…, Ä‡, Ä™, Å‚, Å„, Ã³, Å›, Åº, Å¼). Verify characters are correctly decoded and preserved through the parsing process.

subtasks.title: Enhance error messaging and user feedback
subtasks.description: Improve error messages in upload widget and parser to provide actionable feedback for edge cases
subtasks.details: Update the upload-widget.tsx error handling (lines 153-160) and smart-csv-parser.ts error collection to provide more specific and actionable error messages. Replace generic errors with specific guidance: 'Row X has Y columns but expected Z', 'File appears to use encoding X, try saving as UTF-8', 'Quoted field not properly closed in row X'. Add suggestions for common fixes and links to help documentation. Implement error categorization (critical vs warning vs info).
subtasks.testStrategy: Test error scenarios with malformed files and verify users receive clear, actionable error messages. Test that warnings don't prevent successful parsing of mostly-valid files.

subtasks.title: Add parser configuration options and fallback modes
subtasks.description: Implement configurable parsing options and fallback mechanisms for handling edge cases gracefully
subtasks.details: Extend the SmartCSVParser class to accept configuration options: strict mode vs lenient mode, custom separator detection, encoding hints, maximum allowed malformed rows percentage. Add fallback parsing modes: if intelligent detection fails, try common configurations (comma vs semicolon, with/without quotes). Implement parser recovery: attempt to parse file with different settings if initial attempt fails. Add option to skip problematic rows and continue processing valid ones.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test parser with various edge case files using different configuration options. Verify fallback modes activate appropriately and that lenient parsing can recover from minor formatting issues while maintaining data integrity.

subtasks.title: Implement Distributed Rate Limiting with Redis

tasks.title: Enhance Security Headers and Rate Limiting
tasks.description: Complete security implementation by adding headers to error responses and improving rate limiting system
tasks.details: Add security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, etc.) to error responses. Implement X-RateLimit-* headers for debugging. Migrate from in-memory rate limiting to Redis for production scalability. Add IP-based and user-based rate limiting tiers.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify security headers present in all response types, test rate limiting behavior under various load conditions, confirm Redis integration works in distributed environment

subtasks.title: Migrate Rate Limiting Backend to Redis
subtasks.description: Replace the current in-memory rate limiting store with a Redis-based solution to support scalability and persistence in a distributed production environment.
subtasks.details: Set up Redis client and connection management within the application. Refactor the existing rate limiting middleware to use Redis commands (e.g., INCR, EXPIRE) for tracking request counts. Use environment variables for Redis connection details (host, port, password).
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify that the application connects to Redis successfully. Run basic load tests to confirm that request counts are being tracked correctly in Redis and that limits are enforced.

subtasks.title: Implement Tiered Rate Limiting Logic
subtasks.description: Enhance the rate limiting system to support multiple tiers: a stricter limit for unauthenticated requests (IP-based) and a more generous limit for authenticated users (user-ID-based).
subtasks.details: Modify the rate limiting middleware to differentiate between authenticated and unauthenticated requests. Use the request's IP address as the Redis key for unauthenticated users and the user's unique ID for authenticated users. Define configurable limits and time windows for each tier.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test that unauthenticated requests from the same IP are correctly limited. Test that authenticated users have a separate, higher limit. Verify that limits for one user do not affect another.

subtasks.title: Add Security Headers to Error Responses
subtasks.description: Harden the application by ensuring that all server-generated error responses (e.g., 404 Not Found, 500 Internal Server Error) include essential security headers.
subtasks.details: Configure a global middleware or modify the application's central error handling logic to inject `Content-Security-Policy` (CSP), `X-Frame-Options`, `X-Content-Type-Options`, and `Strict-Transport-Security` headers into all 4xx and 5xx HTTP responses.
subtasks.testStrategy: Trigger various error conditions (e.g., request a non-existent page, force a server error) and inspect the response headers to confirm that all required security headers are present and correctly configured.

subtasks.title: Implement X-RateLimit-* Informational Headers
subtasks.description: Add standard `X-RateLimit-*` headers to API responses to provide clients with real-time feedback on their rate limit status for improved debugging and client-side handling.
subtasks.details: In the rate limiting middleware, after processing a request, calculate and add the following headers to the response: `X-RateLimit-Limit` (the total limit for the window), `X-RateLimit-Remaining` (requests left in the window), and `X-RateLimit-Reset` (UTC timestamp for when the window resets).
subtasks.testStrategy: Make a series of API calls and verify that the `X-RateLimit-Remaining` header value decreases with each call. Confirm that the `X-RateLimit-Limit` reflects the correct tier and that `X-RateLimit-Reset` is a valid future timestamp.

subtasks.title: End-to-End Testing and Production Configuration
subtasks.description: Verify the complete implementation of the enhanced security and rate limiting systems in a staging/production-like environment and finalize configuration.
subtasks.details: Configure production-level rate limits and Redis connection strings in the Vercel environment. Perform load testing to validate IP-based and user-based limits under concurrent load. Write automated integration tests to assert the presence of security headers on error responses and `X-RateLimit-*` headers on all API responses.
subtasks.testStrategy: Simulate a distributed environment to confirm Redis integration works as expected. Run a full test suite covering all security and rate limiting features to ensure no regressions were introduced and that the system is production-ready.

tasks.title: Fix Critical CSV Parser Failures for Production Files
tasks.description: Resolve a critical production deployment blocker by fixing the CSV parser, which currently fails on multiple required file formats and times out on large files. This is core functionality that must work for all specified customer files.
tasks.details: The current parser is failing on 3 of 4 sample files, including errors like 'failed to parse file' and 'ERR_TIMED_OUT' on large uploads. The fix requires a more robust parsing strategy. First, analyze the failing files ('2025-10-02.xlsx - wzorcowy zakres danych.csv', 'atal - Dane.csv', 'Ceny-ofertowe-mieszkan-dewelopera-inpro_s__a-2025-10-02.csv') to identify issues with delimiters, character encoding (e.g., UTF-8 vs. Windows-1250), and file structure. Replace or augment the existing parser with a powerful, streaming-capable library like PapaParse. This is essential to process large files (e.g., 3.3MB) without consuming excessive memory or hitting execution timeouts. To prevent UI freezes, the entire parsing process should be moved into a Web Worker, offloading the work from the main thread. Error handling must be improved to provide specific feedback to the user (e.g., 'Invalid delimiter detected') and log detailed technical errors to Sentry for easier debugging in the future.

ANALYSIS COMPLETE - ROOT CAUSES IDENTIFIED:

**CRITICAL BUG in delimiter detection logic (line 722):**
- Current naive implementation: `line.includes(';') ? ';' : ','`
- Fatal flaw: Detects semicolons inside quoted field values and mistakenly treats them as delimiters
- Example failure: File uses commas but contains `;` in data like "19a ust. 1 pkt 1), 2) lub 3)" â†’ parser incorrectly selects semicolon

**FILE FORMAT ANALYSIS:**
âœ… 2025-09-11.csv: SEMICOLON delimiter (51 semicolons in header) â†’ WORKS CORRECTLY
âŒ 2025-10-02.xlsx: COMMA delimiter (52 commas in header) + quoted fields â†’ FAILS (wrong delimiter detection)
âŒ atal - Dane.csv: COMMA delimiter (48 commas) + 3.3MB size â†’ FAILS (wrong delimiter + timeout)
âŒ INPRO.csv: COMMA delimiter + likely UTF-8 BOM + quoted fields â†’ FAILS (BOM + wrong delimiter)

**REQUIRED FIXES:**
1. Replace naive `includes()` check with proper delimiter counting in header row only
2. Implement BOM stripping for UTF-8 files (3-byte sequence: 0xEF,0xBB,0xBF)
3. Consider PapaParse integration for robust CSV parsing with streaming support for large files
4. Add proper quoted field handling to prevent delimiter confusion

**PERFORMANCE ISSUE:** Large file (3.3MB) parsing causes browser timeout - streaming parser needed for production scalability.

subtasks.title: Offload CSV Parsing Logic to a Web Worker
subtasks.description: Move the entire PapaParse streaming logic into a Web Worker to prevent the main UI thread from freezing during large file processing.
subtasks.details: Create a `parser.worker.js` file and transfer the PapaParse logic into it. The main application thread will be responsible for creating the worker, posting the file to it, and listening for messages (e.g., `data-chunk`, `parsing-complete`, `parsing-error`). This ensures the UI remains responsive and interactive even when parsing multi-megabyte files.

subtasks.details: Utilize PapaParse's `error` callback within the Web Worker to catch parsing errors. When an error is detected, send a structured message to the main thread containing a user-friendly error message (e.g., 'Invalid delimiter detected') and the technical details. The main thread will display the user-friendly message in the UI. The detailed error object, along with context like the filename, will be logged to Sentry, which depends on the setup from Task 6.

tasks.title: Comprehensive CodeRabbit Code Review and Quality Improvements
tasks.description: Perform a systematic code review of the entire OTORAPORT application using the CodeRabbit CLI to analyze code quality, security, and performance. This effort will produce detailed reports and actionable tasks for improving the codebase.
tasks.details:
This task involves a systematic audit of the entire codebase to identify and document areas for improvement. 

Steps:
1. **Setup:** Ensure the CodeRabbit CLI is installed and authenticated. Create a root directory `.coderabbit-analysis/` to store the output files.
2. **Section-by-Section Review:** Execute the review process on logical sections of the application to ensure thorough coverage and manageable report sizes. Target sections include:
    - API Routes (`/pages/api/` or `/app/api/`)
    - UI Components (`/components/`)
    - Library/Utility functions (`/lib/`, `/utils/`)
    - Hooks (`/hooks/`)
    - Page/Route definitions (`/pages/`, `/app/` excluding api)
    - Configuration files
3. **Execution Command:** For each section, run the CodeRabbit review command. Use the `--plain` flag for a markdown-compatible format and specify a descriptive output file. Example: `coderabbit review ./components/dashboard --plain --output-path .coderabbit-analysis/components-dashboard.md`
4. **Analysis and Documentation:** As reports are generated, review the findings. Create a summary document that categorizes all identified issues as 'Critical', 'Warning', or 'Suggestion'. This summary should reference the detailed report files.
5. **Actionable Task Creation:** For every issue that requires a code change, create a new, well-defined follow-up task in the project management system. Each new task should include a link to the relevant section of the CodeRabbit report and a clear description of the required fix.
tasks.testStrategy:
Verification for this task is based on the completeness and actionability of the review process. 
1. **Verify Report Generation:** Confirm that the `.coderabbit-analysis/` directory contains markdown reports for all major code sections (API, components, libs, etc.).
2. **Review Report Content:** Spot-check several reports to ensure they contain meaningful analysis from CodeRabbit regarding code quality, potential bugs, performance, and security.
3. **Check for Summary:** Ensure a summary document or a master ticket exists that prioritizes the most critical findings from all reports.
4. **Confirm Task Creation:** Verify that new tasks have been created in the project backlog for high-priority issues identified during the review. The primary success criterion is a well-documented and prioritized list of technical debt and improvement tasks.

tasks.title: Fix Critical Parsing Errors to Unblock Build
tasks.description: Resolve a critical build failure caused by corrupted character encoding in two React components (`error-boundary.tsx` and `breadcrumb.tsx`), which is currently blocking all TypeScript compilation and deployments.
tasks.details:
This task addresses a build-blocking issue originating from corrupted character encoding in two critical UI files, likely caused by improper handling of escaped quotes. The solution involves replacing the corrupted files with clean, standard implementations.

1.  **Remove Corrupted Files:** First, delete the problematic files to prevent any residual encoding issues. Remove `src/components/error-boundary.tsx` and `src/components/ui/breadcrumb.tsx`.

2.  **Recreate Error Boundary:** Create a new file at `src/components/error-boundary.tsx`. Implement a robust React Error Boundary using the standard class component pattern. This component should use `getDerivedStateFromError` to capture errors during rendering and update its state to display a fallback UI. It should also use `componentDidCatch` to log the error details for debugging purposes.

3.  **Recreate Breadcrumb Component:** Create a new file at `src/components/ui/breadcrumb.tsx`. Fetch the official, clean source code for the Breadcrumb component directly from the `shadcn/ui` library's documentation or GitHub repository. This ensures the component is free from any custom modifications or encoding errors.

4.  **Integrate and Verify:** Ensure the newly created `ErrorBoundary` component is wrapped around the main application layout or route switch to catch runtime errors globally. Confirm the `Breadcrumb` component is correctly imported and used where needed.
tasks.testStrategy:
The verification process must confirm that the build is unblocked and that the replaced components function as expected.

1.  **Static Analysis:** Run `npx tsc --noEmit` in the terminal. The command must complete successfully with zero reported TypeScript errors.

2.  **Build Verification:** Execute the production build command, `npm run build`. The process must complete without any errors, producing a valid build artifact.

3.  **Error Boundary Functional Test:** To test the error boundary, temporarily introduce a component that intentionally throws an error (e.g., `throw new Error('Simulated UI Error');`) within the boundary's scope. When loading the page, verify that the user-friendly fallback UI is displayed instead of a blank screen or crashed application. Remove the test error afterward.

4.  **Breadcrumb Functional Test:** Navigate to several pages that utilize the breadcrumb component. Verify that it renders correctly, the navigation path is accurate for each page, and all links within the breadcrumb are active and navigate to the correct routes upon clicking.

tasks.title: Implement Type Safety - Fix 82 'any' Types
tasks.description: Systematically replace 82 instances of the 'any' type across the codebase to enhance type safety, prevent runtime errors, and enable strict TypeScript compilation. This task focuses on key areas like API routes, data parsers, and utility functions.
tasks.details:
This task addresses a significant code quality issue identified in the CodeRabbit analysis (ESLINT_ANALYSIS.md), which found 82 instances of the 'any' type. The goal is to refactor the codebase to be strictly typed, reducing the risk of production runtime errors.

**1. Initial Setup:**
- In `tsconfig.json`, set `"strict": true` and `"noImplicitAny": true`. This will reveal all instances of implicit and explicit 'any' that need to be addressed.

**2. API Route Typing (e.g., `src/app/api/upload/route.ts`):**
- Define explicit types for API request bodies and responses. Utilize Zod for runtime validation and type inference.
- Example:
  `import { z } from 'zod';`
  `const UploadRequestSchema = z.object({ fileContent: z.string(), fileName: z.string() });`
  `type UploadRequest = z.infer<typeof UploadRequestSchema>;`
- Refactor route handlers to use these types: `export async function POST(request: NextRequest) { const body: UploadRequest = await request.json(); ... }`

**3. Parser Typing (`smart-csv-parser.ts`, `papaparse-csv-parser.ts`):**
- Define a central, canonical type for property data, e.g., `MinistryProperty`, in a shared types file like `src/types/ministry.ts`.
- Refactor parser functions to return strongly-typed arrays, such as `(csvData: string): MinistryProperty[]`.
- For third-party libraries like PapaParse that return mixed or unknown types, create specific wrapper types or use generics to handle the data safely before mapping it to the `MinistryProperty` type. Avoid casting with `as any`.

**4. Utility and Component Typing (`bulk-operations.ts`, `admin-dashboard.tsx`):**
- For utility functions, replace `any` with specific interfaces or generics. If a function operates on different but related object shapes, generics are ideal: `function getField<T, K extends keyof T>(obj: T, key: K): T[K] { ... }`
- For React components, define explicit `Props` interfaces. For data fetched from APIs (e.g., with `useSWR` or `react-query`), provide the expected data type to the hook: `const { data } = useSWR<DashboardData>('/api/dashboard');`

**5. Documenting Justified 'any' Usage:**
- The goal is to reduce 'any' usage to fewer than 20 instances.
- For any remaining, legitimate uses (e.g., interfacing with a complex, untyped external library), they must be made explicit and documented.
- Use an ESLint disable comment with a clear justification: `// eslint-disable-next-line @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any -- Justification: Interfacing with legacy library X whose type definitions are incomplete.`
tasks.testStrategy:
Verification will focus on static analysis and regression testing to ensure type safety is achieved without breaking existing functionality.

**1. Static Analysis & Linting:**
- Run `npx tsc --noEmit` from the project root. The command must complete successfully with zero TypeScript errors reported.
- Run the linter across the entire codebase. There should be no `no-explicit-any` errors, except for the <20 explicitly disabled and documented instances.
- Use a code search (e.g., `grep -r 'any' src/ | wc -l`) to confirm the total count of 'any' is below the target of 20.

**2. API Route Verification:**
- Using a tool like Postman or Insomnia, send requests to the refactored API endpoints (especially `/api/upload`).
- Test with both valid and invalid request bodies. Valid bodies should be processed successfully. Invalid bodies should return a 400 Bad Request error with a descriptive message from the Zod validation.

**3. Parser Functionality Test:**
- Re-run the entire test suite from Task #11, which uses multiple production CSV files.
- Confirm that all sample files ('2025-10-02.xlsx - wzorcowy zakres danych.csv', 'atal - Dane.csv', etc.) are still parsed successfully without errors or timeouts.
- Add unit tests to verify that the output of the parser functions strictly conforms to the `MinistryProperty[]` type.

**4. Frontend UI Regression Testing:**
- Manually navigate the application, focusing on pages that use the refactored code, such as the Admin Dashboard.
- Verify that all data is displayed correctly and that there are no new runtime errors in the browser's developer console.
- In the IDE (e.g., VS Code), confirm that type inference and IntelliSense work correctly for variables and function return values in the modified files.

tasks.title: Fix Security Vulnerabilities - Resolve 30 XSS Issues from Unescaped Entities
tasks.description: Address 30 potential Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities identified by the `react/no-unescaped-entities` ESLint rule. This involves correcting unescaped characters in JSX across privacy, terms of service, and component files to enhance application security.
tasks.details:
This task focuses on eliminating 30 specific lint warnings for unescaped entities in React, as documented in `.coderabbit-analysis/ESLINT_ANALYSIS.md`. These warnings represent potential XSS vulnerabilities and can cause rendering issues. **Implementation Steps:** 1. **Baseline Analysis:** Run `npm run lint` to confirm the 30 `react/no-unescaped-entities` warnings are present in the codebase. This verifies the initial state before making changes. 2. **Automated Fix:** Execute `npm run lint -- --fix`. This command will automatically correct simple cases, such as replacing a single quote `'` with `'`. 3. **Manual Review and Correction:** The auto-fix will not resolve all issues, particularly those involving double quotes. Manually inspect the auto-fixed code and address remaining warnings in the following files: * `src/app/privacy/page.tsx` (20 instances) * `src/app/terms/page.tsx` (6 instances) * `src/components/CustomDomainManager.tsx` (4 instances) 4. **Apply Correct Escaping Patterns:** For remaining issues, use one of the following standard React patterns: * **JSX Expression (Preferred for dynamic or simple strings):** Wrap the string or the problematic part in curly braces. * *Before:* `

The "smart" parser

` * *After:* `

The {"smart"} parser

` * **HTML Entities (Preferred for static, typographic content):** Replace characters with their named HTML entity codes. * *Before:* `

The "smart" parser

` * *After:* `

The “smart” parser

` 5. **Final Linting:** Once all manual fixes are applied, run `npm run lint` again to ensure that zero `react/no-unescaped-entities` warnings are reported.
tasks.testStrategy:
Verification will combine static analysis with manual UI testing to ensure both security compliance and visual correctness.

1.  **Static Analysis (Primary Success Criterion):**
    *   Execute `npm run lint` from the project root.
    *   Confirm the command completes successfully with **zero** reported `react/no-unescaped-entities` warnings.

2.  **Visual & Functional Regression Testing:**
    *   Launch the application and navigate to the `/privacy` and `/terms` pages.
    *   Thoroughly review all content to confirm that text renders correctly, especially around quotes and special characters. Ensure no raw HTML entities (e.g., `“`) are visible to the user.
    *   Verify that the page layout and styling are unchanged and that there are no visual regressions.

3.  **Component-Specific Testing:**
    *   Access the part of the application that utilizes the `CustomDomainManager.tsx` component.
    *   Confirm that the component renders correctly and that its functionality is not broken.

4.  **Cross-Browser Check:**
    *   Briefly load the `/privacy` and `/terms` pages in at least two different modern browsers (e.g., Chrome, Firefox) to check for consistent rendering of the corrected text.

tasks.title: Improve Code Quality - Clean Unused Code
tasks.description: Refactor the codebase to eliminate 39 unused variable warnings and resolve 9 React hooks dependency warnings identified by ESLint. This task will improve code maintainability, reduce bloat, and prevent potential bugs from stale closures.
tasks.details:
**1. Resolve React Hooks Dependency Warnings (9 issues):**
   - Run `npm run lint` to locate all `react-hooks/exhaustive-deps` warnings, focusing on `src/components/analytics/analytics-dashboard.tsx` and `src/components/help/GuidedTour.tsx`.
   - For each `useEffect`, `useMemo`, or `useCallback`, analyze the missing dependencies. Add the required state variables or props to the dependency array.
   - If a function used inside an effect is causing a warning, wrap its definition in `useCallback` with its own dependencies to stabilize it across re-renders.
   - As a last resort, if a dependency is intentionally omitted (e.g., for a one-time setup effect), add an `// eslint-disable-next-line react-hooks/exhaustive-deps` comment on the line above the dependency array. Include a brief comment explaining why the omission is safe and intentional.

**2. Remove Unused Variables (39 issues):**
   - Use the `no-unused-vars` warnings from `npm run lint` as a checklist.
   - **Unused Imports:** Delete entire import lines for components and functions that are no longer used (e.g., `findRelevantKnowledge`, `KnowledgeItem`).
   - **Unused Function Parameters:** In API routes (`src/app/api/upload/route.ts`) and library functions (`src/lib/database.ts`), remove unused parameters. If a parameter's position is required by a function signature, prefix it with an underscore (e.g., `_request`, `_userId`) to signal to the linter that it is intentionally unused.
   - **Unused Error Catches:** In `try...catch` blocks where the caught error object is not used, simplify the block. Use `catch {}` if your project's ECMAScript version supports it, or `catch (_error)` otherwise, to remove the warning.
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. Static Analysis (Success Criterion):**
   - Execute `npm run lint` from the project root.
   - Verify that the command completes successfully with **zero** `no-unused-vars` and **zero** `react-hooks/exhaustive-deps` warnings reported (excluding those explicitly disabled with documented justification).

**2. Regression Testing:**
   - Run the complete automated test suite via `npm run test`. Confirm that all existing tests pass without any new failures or warnings.

**3. Manual Functional Verification:**
   - Manually navigate and interact with the features associated with the modified files.
   - **Analytics Dashboard:** Verify that all charts and data displays in `analytics-dashboard.tsx` load and update correctly.
   - **Guided Tour:** Trigger and step through the guided tour in `GuidedTour.tsx` to ensure its logic and flow are uninterrupted.
   - **File Upload:** Test the file upload functionality governed by `src/app/api/upload/route.ts` to confirm it still processes files as expected.

tasks.description: Perform a comprehensive final verification to ensure all code quality issues from Tasks 13-16 are resolved and certify the codebase as production-ready.
tasks.details:
This task serves as the final quality gate before deployment, ensuring that all recent refactoring and fixing efforts have been successfully integrated without introducing regressions.

**Verification Steps:**

**1. Full Linting (15 min)**
   - Execute `npm run lint` from the project root to analyze the entire codebase.
   - Verify the output shows fewer than 20 total warnings, all confirmed as low priority.
   - Ensure the command reports zero errors.

**2. Full TypeScript Check (15 min)**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` to perform a static type-check across all files.
   - Confirm the process completes with zero compilation errors.
   - Briefly open a few complex components in the IDE to verify that type inference and autocompletion are working as expected.

**3. Full Production Build (15 min)**
   - Execute the production build command: `npm run build`.
   - Verify that the build completes successfully without any errors or critical warnings.
   - Check the build output summary to ensure final bundle sizes are within acceptable ranges, consistent with the goals of Task 9.

**4. Generate Final Report (15 min)**
   - Update the final verification document located at `.coderabbit-analysis/FINAL_VERIFICATION.md`.
   - Document key before/after metrics, such as ESLint error/warning counts, TypeScript errors, and build success status, referencing the initial state from `.coderabbit-analysis/MASTER_SUMMARY.md`.
   - Write a concise summary for stakeholders confirming that all planned code quality improvements are complete and the application is certified production-ready.
tasks.testStrategy:
The success of this task is measured by a series of automated checks and the final documentation, confirming the codebase meets production standards.

**Success Criteria:**

- **ESLint:** The `npm run lint` command must complete with fewer than 20 warnings and exactly 0 errors.
- **TypeScript:** The `npx tsc --noEmit` command must report 0 compilation errors.
- **Build:** The `npm run build` command must succeed without errors.
- **Fix Verification:** All fixes from the preceding code quality tasks (Tasks 13, 14, 15, 16) must be implicitly verified by the success of the linting, type-checking, and build processes.
- **Certification:** A final report in `.coderabbit-analysis/FINAL_VERIFICATION.md` must be created, certifying the codebase as 'production-ready'.

tasks.title: Fix Critical Build Error: GuidedTour.tsx TDZ ReferenceError
tasks.description: Resolve a critical build-blocking Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) ReferenceError in GuidedTour.tsx where useCallback functions are referenced before initialization, preventing production builds from completing.
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. Development Testing:**
   - Start the development server with `npm run dev`
   - Navigate to a page that uses GuidedTour component
   - Activate a tour and verify it initializes without console errors
   - Test all tour navigation functions (next, previous, skip, complete)

**2. Static Analysis:**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` to verify TypeScript compilation succeeds
   - Check that no TDZ-related errors are reported

**3. Production Build Test:**
   - Execute `npm run build` command
   - Verify the build completes successfully without 'Cannot access before initialization' errors
   - Confirm the /dashboard route prerendering succeeds

**4. Runtime Verification:**
   - Test tour functionality in the built application
   - Verify all callback functions execute correctly
   - Confirm setTimeout functions inside completeCurrentStep work as expected

**Success Criteria:**
   - Zero TDZ ReferenceErrors during build process
   - GuidedTour component renders and functions normally
   - Production build completes successfully
   - All tour navigation and completion flows work correctly

subtasks.title: Analyze and Confirm TDZ Error Source in GuidedTour.tsx
subtasks.description: Pinpoint the exact lines of code in `src/components/help/GuidedTour.tsx` causing the Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) ReferenceError by reviewing the specified code block and replicating the build failure.
subtasks.details: Examine lines 78-97 in `src/components/help/GuidedTour.tsx`. Confirm that the `completeCurrentStep` useCallback function's dependency array includes `completeTour` and `nextStep`, which are defined later in the file. Run `npm run build` to verify that this structure causes the 'Cannot access before initialization' error, validating the problem analysis.
subtasks.testStrategy: The build command `npm run build` should fail with a ReferenceError pointing to the `completeTour` or `nextStep` functions, confirming the initial state.

subtasks.title: Hoist `completeTour` and `nextStep` Function Definitions
subtasks.description: Refactor `GuidedTour.tsx` by moving the `completeTour` and `nextStep` function definitions to a position before the `completeCurrentStep` function that depends on them.
subtasks.details: Cut the `useCallback` definitions for `completeTour` (from around line 186) and `nextStep` (from around line 192). Paste these code blocks before the `useCallback` definition for `completeCurrentStep` (at line 78) to resolve the initialization order.
subtasks.testStrategy: After moving the code, run a static analysis check like `npx tsc --noEmit` to ensure no new immediate TypeScript errors have been introduced by the reordering.

subtasks.title: Verify and Adjust Dependencies of Hoisted Functions
subtasks.description: After reordering the functions, meticulously check that all dependencies required by the moved `completeTour` and `nextStep` functions are available and correctly declared at their new location.
subtasks.details: Review the dependency arrays of the now-hoisted `completeTour` and `nextStep` functions. Ensure that any variables or functions they rely on (e.g., `trackTourEvent`, `cleanupHighlight`, `onComplete`, `startStep`) are declared before them or are stable references that do not violate the rules of hooks.
subtasks.testStrategy: Perform a manual code review of the modified file, focusing on the scope and declaration order of all variables and functions used within the refactored `completeTour` and `nextStep` hooks.

subtasks.title: Conduct Development-Mode Functional Testing of Guided Tour
subtasks.description: Run the application in development mode and test the Guided Tour component's full functionality to ensure the refactoring did not introduce any runtime regressions.
subtasks.details: Start the development server using `npm run dev`. Navigate to a page that uses the `GuidedTour` component. Activate a tour and systematically test all user interactions: proceeding to the next step, going to the previous step, skipping the tour, and completing the final step. Monitor the browser's developer console for any new errors.
subtasks.testStrategy: Activate the tour and verify it initializes without console errors. Test all tour navigation functions (next, previous, skip, complete) to confirm they work as expected.

subtasks.title: Execute and Verify Production Build Success
subtasks.description: Confirm the fix by running the production build command and ensuring it completes successfully without the original TDZ ReferenceError.
subtasks.details: In the project's root directory, execute the production build script (`npm run build`). The build process must complete with a zero exit code, specifically verifying the absence of the 'Cannot access before initialization' error. This is the final validation that the build-blocking issue is resolved.
subtasks.testStrategy: The `npm run build` command must complete successfully, producing a build artifact without any TDZ or ReferenceError messages in the console output.

tasks.title: Fix Memory Leak in GuidedTour Event Listeners
tasks.description: Resolve memory leak issue in GuidedTour.tsx where event listeners are not properly cleaned up due to ref overwriting, causing multiple event handler invocations and memory leaks.
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. Memory Leak Verification:**
   - Open browser DevTools and navigate to Memory tab
   - Start a guided tour with multiple steps that have action_required = true
   - Take a heap snapshot before starting the tour
   - Complete several tour steps, triggering multiple event listener attachments
   - Take another heap snapshot and compare to identify reduced memory usage
   - Verify that old event handlers are properly garbage collected

**2. Event Handler Testing:**
   - Start a tour with click-required actions
   - Click on highlighted elements and verify only one event fires per click
   - Use browser DevTools Event Listeners panel to confirm only one click listener is attached to tour elements
   - Test rapid step transitions to ensure cleanup happens before new listeners are added

**3. Functional Regression Testing:**
   - Complete full guided tours with various step types (click, hover, etc.)
   - Verify tour progression works correctly after the fix
   - Test tour cancellation mid-way to ensure proper cleanup
   - Confirm highlight cleanup still works when elements are removed from DOM

**4. Console Error Verification:**
   - Monitor browser console for any 'Cannot remove event listener' errors
   - Ensure no JavaScript errors occur during tour step transitions
   - Verify cleanup function executes without exceptions when called multiple times

subtasks.title: Introduce `attachedActionHandlerRef` for Stable Handler Reference
subtasks.description: Add a new React ref, `attachedActionHandlerRef`, to `src/components/help/GuidedTour.tsx` to persist the reference to the event handler function that is actively attached to a DOM element.
subtasks.details: In `GuidedTour.tsx`, declare a new ref: `const attachedActionHandlerRef = useRef<(() => void) | null>(null);`. This ref will solve the core issue where the handler reference is lost when `handleRequiredActionRef` is overwritten between tour steps.

subtasks.title: Update `highlightElement` to Store Handler in `attachedActionHandlerRef`
subtasks.description: Modify the `highlightElement` function to store the current event handler in `attachedActionHandlerRef` immediately before attaching it to an element's 'click' event.
subtasks.details: In the `highlightElement` function (around lines 136-138), update the logic to first assign the handler to the new ref and then use that ref for the `addEventListener` call. The code should be changed to: `attachedActionHandlerRef.current = handleRequiredActionRef.current; element.addEventListener('click', attachedActionHandlerRef.current);`.

subtasks.title: Refactor `cleanupHighlight` to Use Stable Ref for Listener Removal
subtasks.description: Update the `cleanupHighlight` function to use `attachedActionHandlerRef` to correctly remove the event listener, ensuring the reference matches the one used for attachment.
subtasks.details: In the `cleanupHighlight` function (lines 45-47), change `tourState.highlightedElement.removeEventListener('click', handleRequiredActionRef.current)` to `tourState.highlightedElement.removeEventListener('click', attachedActionHandlerRef.current)`. This guarantees that the correct listener instance is removed.

subtasks.title: Implement Ref Nullification in `cleanupHighlight`
subtasks.description: After successfully removing the event listener in `cleanupHighlight`, set `attachedActionHandlerRef.current` to `null` to prevent stale references and ensure a clean state.
subtasks.details: Add the line `attachedActionHandlerRef.current = null;` inside the `if (attachedActionHandlerRef.current)` block in the `cleanupHighlight` function, immediately after the `removeEventListener` call.

subtasks.title: Verify Memory Leak Resolution and Tour Functionality
subtasks.description: Perform memory profiling and functional testing to confirm that the event listener leak is fixed and that the guided tour's interactive steps work as expected.
subtasks.details: Manually trigger a guided tour with multiple steps requiring a 'click' action. Use the browser's developer tools to monitor event listener counts and take heap snapshots to verify that listeners are being garbage collected after each step.
subtasks.testStrategy: 1. Open browser DevTools (Memory tab). 2. Start a guided tour with multiple `action_required: true` steps. 3. Take a heap snapshot. 4. Advance through several steps. 5. Take another heap snapshot and compare. There should be no increase in detached `GuidedTour` event listeners or related DOM nodes. 6. Functionally verify that clicking on highlighted elements correctly advances the tour.

tasks.title: Restore Cache Purge Functionality in performance.ts

tasks.details:

In `src/lib/performance.ts` lines 451-453 and 456-458, the `purgeCloudflare()` and `purgeVercel()` methods lost their `paths: string[]` parameters during Task 16 cleanup. The `purgeCache()` method on line 439 and 441 still calls these methods with paths array, but the methods no longer accept this parameter, breaking cache invalidation functionality.

**Implementation Steps:**

   - Update line 456: `private static async purgeVercel(): Promise<boolean>` â†’ `private static async purgeVercel(paths: string[]): Promise<boolean>`

2. **Add Parameter Validation:**

   - Throw descriptive error or return false if paths is empty or undefined

   - In `purgeVercel()`: Add TODO comment for Vercel API integration using paths parameter

**Expected File Changes:**

- Line 456: Add `paths: string[]` parameter to purgeVercel method
- Add validation logic inside both methods

2. **Method Signature Verification:**

   - Verify both purgeCloudflare(paths) and purgeVercel(paths) calls compile without errors
   - Check that no other callers of these methods exist that would break

3. **Runtime Testing:**
   - Call CDNManager.purgeCache(['/test-path']) and verify it doesn't throw errors
   - Verify both purge methods receive the paths parameter correctly
   - Test with empty array to ensure validation works

4. **Integration Test:**

   - Verify paths are properly passed through the call chain
   - Confirm methods can handle both single paths and multiple paths arrays

tasks.title: Fix Type Mismatch in bulk-operations.ts
tasks.description: Resolve critical TypeScript compilation errors in src/lib/bulk-operations.ts where BulkExportOptions interface doesn't match bulkExportData method parameters, causing build failures.
tasks.details:
**Problem Analysis:**

In `src/lib/bulk-operations.ts`, there are type mismatches between:
1. `BulkExportOptions` interface (lines 79-83) defines `includeProjects?: boolean` and `includeAnalytics?: boolean` as optional
2. `bulkExportData` method signature (lines 216-221) has inline type with `includeProjects: boolean` and `includeAnalytics: boolean` as required, plus an unused `dateRange?: { from: string, to: string }` field
3. `processBulkExport` method (line 458) expects `BulkExportOptions` type
4. The call on line 254 passes the inline type to processBulkExport, causing type mismatch

**Implementation Steps:**

1. **Update BulkExportOptions interface** (lines 79-83):
   - Add `dateRange?: { from: string, to: string }` field to match method usage
   - Keep `includeProjects` and `includeAnalytics` as optional to maintain backward compatibility

2. **Update bulkExportData method signature** (lines 216-221):
   - Replace inline type with `options: BulkExportOptions`
   - Remove the redundant inline type definition

3. **Verify method implementation** (lines 479-499):
   - Ensure the method handles optional fields correctly with proper null checks
   - Verify `dateRange` field is either used or safely ignored

4. **Run type checking**:
   - Execute `npx tsc --noEmit` to confirm all type errors are resolved
   - Verify no new type errors are introduced

**Expected Changes:**
- Line 216: `async bulkExportData(developerId: string, options: BulkExportOptions): Promise<string> {`
- Lines 79-83: Add `dateRange?: { from: string, to: string }` to BulkExportOptions interface
- Remove lines 217-221 (inline type definition)
- Update line 254 call site to maintain compatibility
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. TypeScript Compilation Test:**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` from project root
   - Verify zero TypeScript errors related to bulk-operations.ts
   - Confirm no new type errors are introduced in other files

**2. Method Signature Verification:**
   - Examine lines 216, 254, and 458 to ensure consistent BulkExportOptions usage
   - Verify all call sites of bulkExportData method accept the updated signature
   - Confirm processBulkExport method properly handles optional fields

**3. Interface Compatibility Test:**
   - Verify BulkExportOptions interface includes all fields used in implementation
   - Test that optional fields (includeProjects, includeAnalytics, dateRange) are handled gracefully
   - Ensure method works with both minimal and full option objects

**4. Build Verification:**
   - Run `npm run build` to ensure production build succeeds
   - Verify no runtime errors in bulk export functionality
   - Test export operations with various option combinations

**Success Criteria:**
   - TypeScript compilation passes without errors
   - All method signatures use consistent BulkExportOptions type
   - Build process completes successfully
   - Export functionality remains operational

subtasks.details: Read the BulkExportOptions interface definition and compare it with the inline type used in bulkExportData method. Document the differences: 1) includeProjects and includeAnalytics are optional in interface but required in method, 2) dateRange field exists in method but not in interface, 3) format field differs between interface and method signature. Create a clear plan for harmonizing these type definitions.

Keep includeProjects and includeAnalytics as optional boolean fields to maintain backward compatibility. This ensures the interface matches the actual usage in the bulkExportData method.

Remove the inline type definition (lines 217-221).

Add proper checks: `if (options.includeProjects === true)` and `if (options.includeAnalytics === true)` instead of assuming they are always present. Ensure dateRange field is either properly used or safely ignored in the implementation.

tasks.title: Fix JSX Unescaped Entities (Auto-fix Available)
tasks.description: Resolve react/no-unescaped-entities lint errors in page.tsx, privacy/page.tsx, and terms/page.tsx by converting unescaped double quotes to HTML entities using automated ESLint fix.
tasks.details:
**Problem Analysis:**

The codebase contains JSX unescaped entity errors in three files where double quotes (`"`) are used directly in JSX text content, violating the react/no-unescaped-entities ESLint rule. Based on analysis:

**Files with unescaped entities:**
- `src/app/page.tsx:794` - Contains `nie "jeÅ›li zÅ‚apiÄ…"` in Polish text
- `src/app/privacy/page.tsx` - Contains multiple instances of unescaped quotes in legal text
- `src/app/terms/page.tsx` - Contains unescaped quotes in terms of service content

**Implementation Steps:**

1. **Run automated ESLint fix:**
   ```bash
   npx eslint --fix src/app/page.tsx src/app/privacy/page.tsx src/app/terms/page.tsx
   ```

2. **Verify automatic conversion:**
   - Double quotes (`"`) should be converted to HTML entities (`"`)
   - Check that text display remains identical in browser
   - Ensure no functional changes to user experience

3. **Manual verification of key instances:**
   - Line 794 in page.tsx: `nie "jeÅ›li zÅ‚apiÄ…"` â†’ `nie "jeÅ›li zÅ‚apiÄ…"`
   - Polish legal text in privacy/page.tsx maintains proper formatting
   - Terms of service text remains readable

4. **Final validation:**
   - Run `npm run lint` to confirm zero react/no-unescaped-entities errors
   - Test pages in browser to ensure text renders correctly
   - Verify all quote marks display properly in Polish content

**Expected Outcome:**
All JSX unescaped entity errors resolved with automated ESLint fix, maintaining exact visual appearance while improving code quality.
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. Automated ESLint Verification:**
   - Run `npx eslint src/app/page.tsx src/app/privacy/page.tsx src/app/terms/page.tsx` before fix to confirm errors
   - Execute `npx eslint --fix` command on the three files
   - Run `npm run lint` to verify zero react/no-unescaped-entities errors remain
   - Confirm ESLint reports clean status for these files

**2. Visual Regression Testing:**
   - Load `/` (landing page) in browser and verify Polish text displays correctly
   - Navigate to `/privacy` and confirm legal text renders with proper quotes
   - Check `/terms` page for correct terms of service formatting
   - Ensure quote marks appear as intended in all Polish language content

**3. Code Review:**
   - Examine converted HTML entities (`"`) in fixed files
   - Verify no functional JSX code was affected, only text content
   - Confirm no additional lint errors were introduced
   - Check that build process completes successfully with `npm run build`

**4. Cross-browser Validation:**
   - Test in Chrome, Firefox, and Safari to ensure consistent quote rendering
   - Verify Polish characters and quotes display correctly across browsers
   - Confirm no accessibility issues with screen readers

**Success Criteria:**
- Zero react/no-unescaped-entities ESLint errors
- All pages render identically to before fix
- Polish text maintains proper quotation marks
- Build and lint processes complete without errors

tasks.title: Regenerate Supabase TypeScript Types
tasks.description: Regenerate corrupted Supabase TypeScript type definitions to resolve 34+ TypeScript compilation errors caused by missing or malformed supabase-generated.ts file.
tasks.details:
**Problem Analysis:**

The codebase currently lacks the critical `src/types/supabase-generated.ts` file, which was deleted (as shown in git status) and is causing widespread TypeScript compilation failures. The project heavily relies on Supabase for database operations and authentication, with 32+ files importing Supabase types.

**Implementation Steps:**

1. **Install Supabase CLI:** Since the CLI is not currently installed, install it using `npm install -g supabase` to enable type generation.

2. **Identify Project Configuration:** Extract the Supabase project ID from environment variables. Based on `.env.example`, look for `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL` in the actual `.env` file to extract the project ID from the URL pattern `https://[project-id].supabase.co`.

3. **Generate Fresh Types:** Execute `npx supabase gen types typescript --project-id <PROJECT_ID> > src/types/supabase-generated.ts` to generate clean TypeScript definitions from the current database schema.

4. **Verify Type Generation:** Check that the generated file contains valid TypeScript without parse errors (TS1434, TS1005) and includes expected interfaces like `Database`, table definitions, and row types.

5. **Validate Compilation:** Run `npx tsc --noEmit` to confirm all TypeScript errors are resolved and the build can proceed successfully.

**Expected File Structure:**
The generated file should contain database interface definitions matching the Supabase schema, including tables for users, properties, subscriptions, and other entities referenced throughout the codebase.
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. Pre-Generation Verification:**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` to document current TypeScript error count
   - Confirm `src/types/supabase-generated.ts` file is missing from the types directory
   - Verify Supabase environment variables are properly configured

**2. Type Generation Testing:**
   - Successfully execute the Supabase CLI type generation command
   - Verify the generated file exists and contains valid TypeScript syntax
   - Check file size is reasonable (should be several KB with database definitions)
   - Inspect file contents for expected interfaces (Database, Tables, etc.)

**3. Compilation Verification:**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` again to confirm zero TypeScript errors
   - Verify specific imports work: check that files importing from `@/types/supabase-generated` no longer show errors
   - Run `npm run build` to ensure the entire build process completes successfully

**4. Integration Testing:**
   - Verify database operations in `src/lib/database.ts` compile correctly
   - Check Supabase client configurations in `src/lib/supabase/` files work with new types
   - Confirm API routes using Supabase types compile without errors

tasks.title: Replace Remaining 46 'any' Types with Proper TypeScript Types
tasks.description: Systematically replace all 46 instances of @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any errors across API routes, components, and lib files with proper TypeScript types to achieve full type safety.
tasks.details:
**Problem Analysis:**

Based on codebase analysis, 46 'any' type instances remain across multiple critical files, representing incomplete type safety from previous cleanup efforts. Key locations include:

**API Routes with 'any' types:**
- `src/app/api/properties/route.ts` - Request/response handling
- `src/app/api/stripe/webhook/route.ts` - Stripe event processing
- `src/app/api/chatbot/route.ts` - OpenAI API integration
- `src/app/api/upload/route.ts` - File upload processing
- `src/app/auth/callback/route.ts` - OAuth type verification

**Library Files with 'any' types:**
- `src/lib/api-response.ts` - Generic response types, error handler wrappers
- `src/lib/error-handler.ts` - Database error processing
- `src/lib/performance.ts` - Performance API entries
- `src/lib/chatbot-security.ts` - Session data and rate limiting
- `src/lib/analytics.ts` - Project/property data processing
- `src/lib/smart-csv-parser.ts` & `src/lib/papaparse-csv-parser.ts` - Dynamic property assignment
- `src/lib/supabase/client.ts` - Cookie management options
- `src/hooks/use-csv-parser-worker.ts` - Parse result data and errors

**Implementation Strategy:**

1. **Replace 'any' with 'unknown' + Type Guards:** For user input and external API responses where structure is uncertain, use 'unknown' with proper type guards and validation.

2. **Create Specific Interfaces:** For known data structures like Stripe webhooks, CSV data, and performance entries, define precise interfaces.

3. **Use Generic Constraints:** For reusable patterns like API responses and error handlers, implement proper generic constraints instead of 'any'.

4. **Type Assertion with Validation:** For dynamic property assignment in CSV parsers, use type assertions with runtime validation.

**Priority Order:**
1. API routes (highest impact on runtime safety)
2. Error handling and security functions
3. Data processing libraries (CSV parsers)
4. UI components and hooks
5. Performance monitoring code

**Specific Actions:**
- Replace `ApiSuccessResponse<T = any>` with proper generic constraints
- Define `StripeWebhookEvent` interface for webhook processing
- Create `CsvParseError` and `ParsedProperty` types for CSV operations
- Replace performance API `(entry as any)` with proper PerformanceEntry extensions
- Define `ChatbotSessionData` interface for security functions
- Use `Record<string, unknown>` for dynamic object patterns where appropriate
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. TypeScript Compilation Verification:**
- Run `npx tsc --noEmit` to ensure zero TypeScript compilation errors
- Verify no new type errors are introduced in dependent files
- Confirm all generic constraints are properly satisfied

**2. ESLint Validation:**
- Execute `npm run lint` and verify zero `@typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any` errors remain
- Ensure no new linting errors are introduced
- Confirm all type assertions are properly justified

**3. Runtime Type Safety Testing:**
- Test API endpoints with malformed payloads to verify type guards work
- Upload various CSV formats to test parser type safety
- Trigger error conditions to verify error handler type safety
- Test Stripe webhook processing with actual webhook payloads

**4. Integration Testing:**
- Run full application build with `npm run build`
- Test authentication flow to verify OAuth callback types
- Verify chatbot functionality with security type checking
- Test file upload flow with new CSV parser types

**5. Performance Monitoring:**
- Verify performance metrics collection still works with typed entries
- Test analytics dashboard with typed project/property data
- Ensure no runtime performance degradation from type changes

**Success Criteria:**
- Zero `@typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any` errors in lint output
- Zero TypeScript compilation errors
- All existing functionality remains intact
- Improved IntelliSense and type checking in development
- Runtime type validation prevents type-related crashes

tasks.title: Fix Error Boundary Parse Errors and Character Encoding Issues
tasks.description: Resolve 108 TypeScript parse errors in src/components/error-boundary.tsx caused by character encoding issues and malformed string literals that are blocking production build compilation.
tasks.details:
**Problem Analysis:**

The error-boundary.tsx file contains 108 TypeScript parse errors stemming from character encoding corruption, specifically invalid character sequences and unterminated string literals. The errors are concentrated around lines 93-169 where Polish text strings contain corrupted characters.

**Root Cause:**
The file appears to have character encoding corruption affecting Polish language strings (e.g., "Ups! CoÅ› poszÅ‚o nie tak", "WystÄ…piÅ‚ nieoczekiwany bÅ‚Ä…d"). The corruption manifests as:
- TS1127: Invalid character errors
- TS1002: Unterminated string literal errors  
- TS1003: Identifier expected errors
- TS1005: ';' expected errors

**Implementation Steps:**

1. **Backup Current File:**
   - Create backup copy of error-boundary.tsx before modifications
   - Document current state for rollback if needed

2. **Character Encoding Analysis:**
   - Identify corrupted Polish text strings in lines 93-169
   - Determine proper UTF-8 encoding for Polish characters (Ä…, Ä‡, Ä™, Å‚, Å„, Ã³, Å›, Åº, Å¼)
   - Analyze string literal boundaries and quote characters

3. **Fix String Literals:**
   - Replace corrupted Polish strings with properly encoded UTF-8 versions:
     - "Ups! CoÅ› poszÅ‚o nie tak" (Something went wrong)
     - "WystÄ…piÅ‚ nieoczekiwany bÅ‚Ä…d" (An unexpected error occurred) 
     - "Przepraszamy za niedogodnoÅ›ci" (We apologize for the inconvenience)
     - "SzczegÃ³Å‚y bÅ‚Ä™du" (Error details)
     - "SprÃ³buj ponownie" (Try again)
     - "OdÅ›wieÅ¼ stronÄ™" (Refresh page)
     - "Strona gÅ‚Ã³wna" (Home page)
   - Ensure proper JSX string escaping and quote matching

4. **Validate JSX Syntax:**
   - Verify all JSX tags are properly closed
   - Check className and other JSX attribute syntax
   - Ensure proper React component structure

5. **File Encoding Verification:**
   - Ensure file is saved with UTF-8 encoding
   - Verify no BOM (Byte Order Mark) corruption
   - Check for invisible characters or encoding artifacts
tasks.testStrategy:
**1. TypeScript Compilation Verification:**
   - Run `npx tsc --noEmit` from project root to verify zero compilation errors
   - Specifically verify error-boundary.tsx compiles cleanly: `npx tsc --noEmit src/components/error-boundary.tsx`

**2. Build Process Testing:**
